captions.text:
Welcome to How To Cook That. I am Ann Reardon
and today we are going to make edible rock

candy geodes. I am going to show you two different
methods of making these. Firstly you are going

to need to make your supersaturated sugar
solution.

So we are going to add three cups of sugar
to one cup of water and put it in a saucepan

and stir it until it is dissolved. If you
lilt up a spoonful and you can still

see those little dots like you can here then
it's to fully dissolved. So keep stirring

until you can lift up a spoonful and if you
just wait a second and the bubbles disperse

you can see it's completely clear.
Then remove it from the heat and add your

desired coloring. And then stir that in well.
Then you can add more coloring until you get

the exact tone that you are after.
The first method that I am going to show you

uses fondant for the outside shell. So I want
you to take some white fondant and roll it

out on some non stick baking paper into a
fairly thin layer. Then take some grey fondant

and add chunks of darker colour to it. If
you are new to working with fondant just click

on the 'cake decorating tutorials' playlist
in the description below this video and there

is a video recipe for fondant and there is
also a video on how to colour fondant there.

Mix it together roughly so that you leave
some different variations in the colors through

the fondant and then roll that out onto another
sheet of non-stick baking paper. And then

rub a small amount of water just across the
top of the surface of your rock colored fondant.

Lift up your white fondant with your baking
paper underneath it and flip it over on top

of the rock colored fondant and then peel
off your paper and smooth it out.

Join two pieces of aluminum foil together
by folding them over a couple of times. Put

that flat on the bench then put down a dishcloths
and a bowl on top of that. Use more foil to

line your bowl and create that uneven rock
shape by putting chunks of foil on different

sides. When you've got the shape you want
just put one more sheet of foil across the

top of the whole thing. Give a light spray
of cooking oil and then place your fondant

rock colour side down over the top of your
bowl and gently press it into place.

Using some scissors trim he fondant so that
it is slightly smaller and then pour your

sugar syrup into that. Wrap up the whole thing
in the alfoil and leave it undisturbed for

at least twelve hours. The sugar in the fondant
is going to cause it to crystalize fairly

quickly. You can pour out the excess syrup
and break off any excess pieces that are formed

if you just want the crystals around the edge.
If you are happy for bigger crystals in the

middle like is in the other one then you can
leave them. Then leave it to dry, I turned

it upside down so it could dry out completely
and then just use a knife to trim off the

excess fondant. The second method of making
the geodes uses chocolate instead of fondant.

For this we are going to take a large bowl
and half fill it with some flour then put

a smaller bowl inside that and add some more
flour to give that uneven rock shape. Place

a sheet of foil over the top . Press it into
place and try and smooth out any of those

folds so that the candy doesn't get stuck
around the aluminum.

Then pour in your sugar syrup, cover it with
foil and then put some cloths over the top

and we are going to leave this one to cool
for about 48 hours.

If you are wondering why i didn't just put
the cold sugar syrup into a chocolate bowl,

let me who you. Here's what happens if you
pour cold sugar syrup into a chocolate easter

egg resting on a cup. Look what happened to
the bottom of the chocolate. So you need to

make your candy first and then your chocolate
second. Lift your foil out of the bowl. Pour

off the excess syrup and gently peel back
the foil. Leave it upside down to dry out

for about half a day.
Melt some candy melts if you're in the USA

or if you are in Australia then nestle white
chocolate melts. You can do that in the microwave,

just 30 seconds and stir it then 20 seconds
and stir, 10 seconds and stir. You need to

keep stirring really well because microwaves
heat unevenly. Put it in for another 10 seconds

and stir. If you don't keep stirring then
one portion of it is going to burn before

the rest is melted. Put it in for another
10 seconds and stir.

Place your rock candy upside down on a glass
and pour over your melts allowing the excess

to drip off onto the paper. Place the excess
back into the bowl and if you want a thicker

white border around the edge of your geode
then add more white chocolate around the edges.

Once that's set then reheat the melts in the
bowl and add a couple of spoons of unsweetened

cocoa powder. Now this is going to make it
thicker and less shiny so that it looks a

bit more rock like. Spoon that over the top
and spread it out and allow the excess to

drip off like you did before. Now I am adding
in some crushed oreo dirt on top to make it

look a bit more rock like. That is optional,
if you want to add that in you can. And then

leave that to set. Lift it off your glass
and you can see your geode in the middle there.

Now you can leave it with the spikes on it
if you like. That looks quite cool. But if

you want it to look exactly like a geode then
take a serrated knife and trim it around the

edges so that it looks like a rock that has
been split in two.

Don't forget to click like if you like the
geodes and share it with your friends. Thank

you to all my lovely subscribers and I'll
see you next week. Bye.
[ music by youtube.com/setsailtv ]

title: Rock Candy Edible Geode HOW TO cook that Rock Candy Recipe Ann Reardon
